alert.note: Alert for Cowley; Sumner (Kansas) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued May 31 at 8:15PM CDT until May 31 at 11:30PM CDT by NWS Wichita
info.description: The National Weather Service in Wichita has extended the * Flash Flood Warning for... Southwestern Cowley County in south central Kansas... Southern Sumner County in south central Kansas... * Until 1130 PM CDT. * At 815 PM CDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 3 and 4 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts up to 1 inch are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly. HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing flash flooding. SOURCE...Radar. IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses. * Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Arkansas City, Winfield, Caldwell, South Haven, Geuda Springs, Hunnewell, Perth and Strother Field Airport. This includes the following highways... Interstate 35 near mile marker 1 and 15. This includes the following streams and drainages... Salt Creek, Chikaskia River, Spring Creek, East Branch Fall Creek, Arkansas City Urban Area, Winser Creek, Walnut River, Posey Creek, Meridian Creek, East Shoo Fly Creek, Negro Creek, Wolf Creek, Beaver Creek, East Badger Creek, Slate Creek, Snyder Creek, Bitter Creek, West Prairie Creek, Bluff Creek, Fall Creek, Middle Bitter Creek, Silver Creek, Big Badger Creek, Prairie Creek, Grouse Creek, Long Creek, Badger Creek, West Shoo Fly Creek, Arkansas River, East Bitter Creek and West Badger Creek. FLASH FLOOD...RADAR INDICATED FLASH FLOOD DAMAGE THREAT...CONSIDERABLE
info.instruction: Do not drive into flooded areas or go around barricades. Nearly two feet of water will carry most vehicles away. Turn around, don`t drown. Move to higher ground now. Act quickly to protect your life. Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding.
